title: Optimizing Firefox for poor connections
content:
Quick background - I live in an internet desert. There is no home internet available and the cell phone service is poor - my only option is to tether my cell phone to be a wi-fi hotspot, but because we are down in the valley relative to the nearest cell phone towers, even this leads to frequent interrupted connections. I often get the message 'No internet access, connected' from my wi-fi connection.

With that situation, how can I set up Firefox to best deal with that reality? In the Netscape days, when universal internet was a rarity, there was a switch for 'text only'. Does that still exist? What else is there to help Firefox out in this situation?

I go into town once a day, and use the open wi-fi from either the library or a coffeeshop for anything that requires uploads, downloads, or streaming. There's an assumption out there that everyone has strong internet access 24/7, and so programmers and designers no longer seem capable of accommodating people with poor connectivity. I would say that this lack of internet is a common problem all across rural Canada, and there doesn't seem to be anything going on to fix it in the immediate future.

All advice gratefully accepted. Doug
